results.name: Number of permutations tau of {1,...,n} such that k*tau(k) + 1 is prime for every k = 1,...,n.
comment: Conjecture: (i) a(n) > 0 for all n > 0. Similarly, for any integer n > 2, there is a permutation tau of {1,...,n} such that k*tau(k) - 1 is prime for every k = 1,...,n.
(ii) For any integer n > 2, there is a permutation tau of {1,...,n} such that k + tau(k) - 1 and k + tau(k) + 1 are twin prime for every k = 1,...,n.

Obviously, part (ii) of this conjecture implies the twin prime conjecture. P. Bradley proved in arXiv:1809.01012 that for any positive integer n there is a permutation tau of {1,...,n} such that k + tau(k) is prime for every k = 1,...,n.
link: Zhi-Wei Sun, Primes arising from permutations, Question 315259 on Mathoverflow, Nov. 14, 2018.
Zhi-Wei Sun, On permutations of {1, ..., n} and related topics, arXiv:1811.10503 [math.CO], 2018.
example: a(3) = 1, and (1,3,2) is a permutation of {1,2,3} with 1*1 + 1 = 2, 2*3 + 1 = 7 and 3*2 + 1 = 7 all prime.
program: (PARI) a(n) = matpermanent(matrix(n, n, i, j, ispseudoprime(i*j + 1))); \\ _Jinyuan Wang_, Jun 13 2020
